facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1807 of 1971 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1807 of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 6, 1971 of the, Patna High Court in C.W.J.C. No. 41 of 197 1.

facts.text: Appeal from Patna High Court judgment and order dated May 6, 1971 in C.W.J.C. No. 41 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 6, 1971 of the, Patna High Court in C.W.J.C. No. 41 of 197 1. M. Singhvi, S. C. Dingra and U. P. Singh, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition before Patna High Court to quash Minister of Forest order dated December 13, 1970 and for mandamus to give effect to order dated November 27, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a writ petition before the High Court of Patnapraying for quashing an order passed by the Minister of Forest, Government of Bihar, on December 13, 1970, and for issue of a writ in the nature of mandamus directing the respondents 1 to 5 to give effect to the previous order of the Minister of Forest dated November 27, 1970.

facts.text: Patna High Court Division Bench dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was heard by a Division Bench of the Court and the petition was dismissed. This appeal, by special leave, is from that judgment.

facts.text: There is a bamboo coup known as Bantha Bamboo coup in Chatra North Division of Hazaribagh district.

anchor.surface_text: There is a bamboo companyp know as Bantha Bamboo companyp in Chatra North Division of Hazaribagh district. On July 22, 1970, the Forest Department of the Government of Bihar advertised for settlement of the right to exploit the COUP by Public auction

facts.text: Forest Department of Bihar advertised for settlement of right to exploit the coup by public auction on July 22, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: On July 22, 1970, the Forest Department of the Government of Bihar advertised for settlement of the right to exploit the COUP by Public auction The auction was held in the Office, of the Divisional Forest Officer on August 7, 1970.

facts.text: Public auction held on August 7, 1970 at Divisional Forest Officer office; five persons including appellant participated.

anchor.surface_text: The auction was held in the Office, of the Divisional Forest Officer on August 7, 1970. Five persons including the appellant participated in the auction.

facts.text: Reserve price fixed at Rs. 95,000/-; appellant's bid of Rs. 92,001/- was highest and provisionally accepted by Divisional Forest Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Though the reserve price fixed in the tender numberice was Rs. 95,000/-, the appellants bid of Rs. 92,001/-, being the highest, was accepted by the Divisional Forest Officer.

facts.text: Appellant deposited security amount of Rs. 23,800/- and executed an agreement after auction.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner thereafter deposited the security amount of Rs. 23,800/- and executed an agreement.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer reported auction to Conservator of Forests, Hazaribagh Circle on August 25, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest officer reported about the auction We servator of Forests, Hazaribagh Circle, by his letter dated August 25, 1970.

facts.text: Papers forwarded to Deputy Secretary, Forest Dept, Govt of Bihar for confirmation since price > Rs. 50,000/- provisional settlement below reserve.

anchor.surface_text: As the price for which the companyp was provisionally, settled exceeded Rs. 50,0001-, the Conservator of Forests forwarded the papers regarding the auction sale to the Deputy Secretary to Government of Bihar, Forest Department, for companytion of the acceptance by the Government.

facts.text: Finance Department asked Divisional Forest Officer why settlement below reserve price.

anchor.surface_text: Since the provisional settlement was made for an amount less than the reserve price, the matter was also referred to the Finance Department. The Finance Department invited companyments from the Divisional Forest Officer as to why the settlement was made for a lesser amount.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer submitted explanation for provisional settlement below reserve on October 30, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest Officer, by his letter dated October 30, 1 970. submitted his explanation for the provisional settlement at an amount below the reserve price.

facts.text: Appellant expressed willingness to take settlement at reserve price of Rs. 95,000/- on October 26, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter was pending before the Government, the appellant expressed his willingness to take the settlement at the-reserve price of Rs. 95,000 by his companymunication dated October 26, 1970.

facts.text: Appellant filed application on November 3, 1970 praying for settlement on basis of highest bid.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter filed an application on November 3, 1970, praying for settlement of the companyp on the basis of the highest bid.

facts.text: Minister of Forest directed on November 27, 1970 that coup be settled with appellant at reserve price.

anchor.surface_text: The Minister of Forest, by his proceedings dated November 27, 1970, directed that the companyp may be settled with the highest bidder. namely the appellant, at the reserve. price.

facts.text: Government sent telegram on November 28, 1970 to Conservator of Forests, Hazaribagh confirming auction sale to appellant at Rs. 95,000/-, copy to Conservator Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: A telegram was sent by the Government to the Conservator of Forests, Hazaribagh Circle on November 28, 1970, with a companyy of the same to the Conservator of Forest, Bihar, companyfirming the auction sale to the appellant at the reserve price of Rs. 95,000/-

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer did not receive intimation of November 28 telegram and did not communicate to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: As numberintimation was received by the Divisional Forest Officer, he did number companymmunicate the proceedings of the Minister to the appellant.

facts.text: Md. Yakub (Respondent No. 6) filed petition on December 4, 1970 offering Rs. 1,01,125/- for settlement.

anchor.surface_text: One Md. Yakub, Respondent No. 6, filed a petition on December 4. 1970, before the Government of Bihar, Respondent No. 1. offering to take the settlement of the companyp in question for Rs. 1,01,125/-

facts.text: Government sent telegram on December 5, 1970 to Divisional Forest Officer directing not to act on November 28 telegram.

anchor.surface_text: A telegram was sent by the Government on December 5, 1970, to the Divisional Forest Officer, directing him number to take any action on the basis of the telegram dated November 28, 1970

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer received December 5 telegram on December 10, 1970 and informed government that previous November 28 telegram not received.

anchor.surface_text: That telegram was received by the Divisional Forest Officer on December 10, 1970. and the Divisional Forest Officer, by his letter dated December 10. 1970, informed the Government that the previous telegram dated November 28, 1970, was number received by him

facts.text: Minister of Forest on December 13, 1970 cancelled settlement with appellant and settled with Respondent No. 6 for Rs. 1,01,125/-

anchor.surface_text: the Minister, by his proceedings dated December 13, 1970, cancelled the settlement of the companyp with appellant and settled the same with Respondent No. 6 for.Rs. 1,01,125/-

facts.text: Government sent telegrams on December 21, 1970 to Conservator and DFO informing settlement with Respondent No. 6.

anchor.surface_text: The Government thereafter sent telegrams on December 21, 1970, to the Conservator of Forests and the Divisional Forest Officer informing them that the companyp had been settled with Respondent No. 6.

facts.text: Divisional Forest Officer on December 23, 1970 directed Respondent No. 6 to deposit security and first instalment; deposited and executed agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Forest Officer. by his letter dated December- 23, 1970, directed Respondent No. 6 to deposit the security amount and to pay the first instalment. Respondent No. 6 deposited the same and executed an agreement.

facts.text: Patna High Court upheld validity of settlement in favour of 6th Respondent and negatived petitioner's contentions.

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated, the High Court negatived these companyten- tions and upheld the validity of the settlement in favour of the 6th Respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court found no concluded contract between appellant and Government.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that there was numberconcluded companytract between the appellant and the Government.

facts.text: Settlement with 6th Respondent not in violation of statutory rules; Rule 10(1) of Rules of Executive Business is directory.

anchor.surface_text: We are number satisfied that the companystruction companytended for is companyrect. Neither rule 10 1  number the rule as relaxed says that forest land can be leased only by public auction.

facts.text: Finance Department not consulted before Minister's order on December 13, 1970 for 6th Respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the records relating to the proceedings for the grant of the lease in favour of the 6th Respondent that the Finance Department was number companysulted before the Minister passed the order on December 13, 1970
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 6, 1971 of the, Patna High Court in C.W.J.C. No. 41 of 197 1.

The appellant filed a writ petition before the High Court of Patnapraying for quashing an order passed by the Minister of Forest, Government of Bihar, on December 13, 1970, and for issue of a writ in the nature of mandamus directing the respondents 1 to 5 to give effect to the previous order of the Minister of Forest dated November 27, 1970.
and for issue of a writ in the nature of mandamus directing the respondents 1 to 5 to give effect to the previous order of the Minister of Forest dated November 27, 1970.

concepts.unlisted_description: Writ directing authorities to give effect to previous order

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant in the writ petition was that there was a concluded contract when the bid of the appellant was accepted by the Divisional Forest Officer though that was subject to confirmation by the Government and that, when the Government confirmed the acceptance by its proceedings, dated November 27, 1970, it was no longer within the power of Government to make the settlement of the coup upon the 6th Respondent by its proceedings dated December 13, 1970.

concepts.interpretation: No concluded contract as there was no confirmation of the provisional acceptance of the bid at Rs.92,001/-; the Minister accepted a new offer at reserve price but it was not communicated and later revoked.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: es fifty thousand  each, subject to the following companyditions that - Reserve price of the company

concepts.unlisted_description: Binding agreement formed by offer and acceptance

anchor.surface_text: the settlement in favour of the 6th Respondent by a private treaty was in violation of the, rules of executive business made under Article 166 3 .

concepts.unlisted_description: Constitutional provision for rules of executive business

anchor.surface_text: Rule 10 of the Rules provides 10 1  No department shall, without previous consultation with the Finance Department, authorise any orders  other than orders pursuant to any general or special delegation made by the Finance Department  which  a  either immediately or by their repercussion, will affect the finances of the State, or which, in particular, involve any grant of land or assignment of revenue or concession, grant, lease or licence of mineral or forests, rights or a right to water power of any easement or privilege in respect of such concession.

concepts.interpretation: Requires prior consultation with Finance Department for leases over Rs.50,000/-; relaxation allows public auction under conditions but does not prohibit private treaty; provision is mandatory due to negative language and public duty.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: he companyditions mentioned there. In other words, rule 10 1  as relaxed does number prohibit the grant of a lease by private treaty. The rule read in

concepts.unlisted_description: Prior consultation with Finance Department for financial orders including forest leases

anchor.surface_text: 2 , Where on a proposal under this rule, prior consultation with the Finance Department is required, but on which the Finance Department might not have agreed, no further action shall be taken on any such proposal until the cabinet takes a decision to this effect.

concepts.interpretation: Prevents further action without Cabinet decision if Finance disagrees.
concepts.unlisted_description: Cabinet decision required if Finance Department disagrees

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that there was a conditional acceptance of the offer of the appellant by the Divisional Forest Officer, that on confirmation by the Government, that acceptance became unconditional and, therefore, there was a concluded contract when the Government confirmed the acceptance, even though the confirmation was not communicated to the appellant.

concepts.interpretation: Provisional acceptance subject to confirmation does not bind until confirmed and communicated; here, no confirmation of original bid and new offer not communicated.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: l Forest Officer though that was subject to companyfirmation by the Government and that, when the Government companyfirmed the acceptance by its proce

concepts.unlisted_description: Acceptance subject to future confirmation or event

anchor.surface_text: In support of this, he relied on The Rajanagaram Village Cooperative Society v. Veerasami Mudaly 1 . There it was held that in the case of a conditional acceptance in the presence of a bidder, the condition being that it is subject to approval or confirmation by some other person, the acceptance, though conditional, has to be communicated and when that is communicated, there is no further need to communicate the approval or confirmation which is the fulfillment of the condition.

concepts.interpretation: Acceptance must be communicated; non-communication prevents contract formation.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the right to, accept a bid of less than Rs. 5,0001-, that acceptance of a bid of more than Rs. 5,0001- by him is subject to companyfirmation by- the

concepts.unlisted_description: Requirement for acceptance to reach offeror

anchor.surface_text: Several tests have been propounded in decided cases for determining the question whether a provision in a statute, or a rule is mandatory or directory. No universal rule, can be laid down on this matter. In each case one must look to the subject matter and consider the importance of the provision disregarded and the relation of that provision to the general object intended to be secured.

concepts.interpretation: Negative language, public duty, revenue concerns make Rule 10(1) mandatory; non-compliance invalidates action.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ust number incorrect to exact a rigorous observance of it as essential to acquisition of the right or authority  see Maxwell, Interpretation of Statut

concepts.unlisted_description: Tests to determine if statutory provision is mandatory or directory based on language, purpose, consequences

issues.text: Whether there was a concluded contract between the appellant and the Government when the bid was provisionally accepted by the Divisional Forest Officer and subsequently confirmed by the Minister

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant in the writ petition was that there was a concluded contract when the bid of the appellant was accepted by the Divisional Forest Officer though that was subject to confirmation by the Government and that, when the Government confirmed the acceptance by its proceedings, dated November 27, 1970, it was no longer within the power of Government to make the settlement of the coup upon the 6th Respondent by its proceedings dated December 13, 1970.

issues.text: Whether there was a conditional acceptance of the appellant's bid that became unconditional upon Government confirmation, even without communication to the appellant

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant contended that there was a conditional acceptance of the offer of the appellant by the Divisional Forest Officer, that on confirmation by the Government, that acceptance became unconditional and, therefore, there was a concluded contract when the Government confirmed the acceptance, even though the confirmation was not communicated to the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the settlement in favour of the 6th Respondent was in violation of any statutory rule

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that there was no concluded contract between the appellant and the Government. This takes us to the question whether the settlement in favour of the 6th Respondent was in violation of any statutory rule. The appellants contention was that the settlement in favour of the 6th Respondent by a private treaty was in violation of the, rules of executive business made under Article 166 3 .

issues.text: Whether the coup was settled in favour of the 6th Respondent in accordance with Rule 10(1)

anchor.surface_text: Now the question is whether the coup in question was settled in favour of the, 6th Respondent in accordance with Rule 10 1 . It is clear from the records relating to the proceedings for the grant of the lease in favour of the 6th Respondent that the Finance Department was not consulted before the Minister passed the order on December 13, 1970, to grant the lease.

issues.text: Whether Rule 10(1) of the Rules of Executive Business, requiring prior consultation with the Finance Department, is mandatory or directory

anchor.surface_text: So, the question arises whether rule 10 1 , in so far as it requires prior consultation with the Finance Department, is only directory in character and therefore, even if there was no prior consultation, the settlement was valid. Several tests have been propounded in decided cases for determining the question whether a provision in a statute, or a rule is mandatory or directory.

arguments.claim: No concluded contract between appellant and Government.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that there was no concluded contract between the appellant and the Government.

holdings.text: There was no concluded contract between the appellant and the Government.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that there was numberconcluded companytract between the appellant and the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisional acceptance of original bid not confirmed by government; subsequent offer to pay reserve price accepted by Minister but not communicated to appellant and revoked by appellant's later application insisting on highest bid.

holdings.text: Rule 10(1) and its relaxation do not prohibit settlement of forest coups by private treaty; they only require prior consultation with Finance Department for leases over Rs. 50,000/-.

anchor.surface_text: We are number satisfied that the companystruction companytended for is companyrect. Neither rule 10 1  number the rule as relaxed says that forest land can be leased only by public auction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading rejects contention that rule mandates public auction only; relaxation permits auctions under conditions but does not bar private treaty if consultation occurs.

holdings.text: Finance Department was not consulted before Minister's order on December 13, 1970 settling coup with 6th Respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the records relating to the proceedings for the grant of the lease in favour of the 6th Respondent that the Finance Department was number companysulted before the Minister passed the order on December 13, 1970

holdings.reasoning_summary: Records of proceedings confirm no consultation occurred prior to the order.

holdings.text: Rule 10(1) of Rules of Executive Business requiring prior consultation with Finance Department is mandatory, not directory.

anchor.surface_text: So, the question arises whether rule 10 1 , in so far as it requires prior consultation with the Finance Department, is only directory in character and therefore, even if there was no prior consultation, the settlement was valid. Several tests have been propounded in decided cases for determining the question whether a provision in a statute, or a rule is mandatory or directory.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Negative language indicates mandatory intent; concerns public revenue and individual rights; applies tests from precedents considering purpose, consequences, public duty without serious inconvenience from enforcement.

precedents.citation: The Rajanagaram Village Cooperative Society v. Veerasami Mudaly 1 1950 11 M.L.J.486.

anchor.surface_text: The Rajanagaram Village Cooperative Society v. Veerasami Mudaly 1 . There it was held that in the case of a conditional acceptance in the presence of a bidder, the condition being that it is subject to approval or confirmation by some other person, the acceptance, though conditional, has to be communicated and when that is communicated, there is nofurther need to communicate the approval or confirmation which is the fulfillment of the condition. It was further held that a conditional acceptance has the effect of binding the highest bidder to the contract if there is subsequent approval or confirma- 1  1950 11 M.L.J.486.

precedents.case_name: Rajanagaram Village Cooperative Society v Veerasami Mudaly
precedents.cited_proposition: conditional acceptance in presence of bidder subject to approval binds the bidder upon confirmation without need to communicate the confirmation to the bidder
precedents.cited_holding: a conditional acceptance has the effect of binding the highest bidder to the contract if there is subsequent approval or confirmation, the contract becomes concluded and enforceable

precedents.citation: Somasudaram Pillai v. provincial Government of Madras 1 A.I.R. 1947,34 Madras, 366.

anchor.surface_text: Somasudaram Pillai v. provincial Government of Madras 1 where Chief Justice Leach, speaking for the Court said that, to have an enforceable contract, there must be an offer and an unconditional acceptance and that a person who makes an offer has the right to withdraw it before acceptance, in the absence of a condition to the contrary supported by consideration. He further said the fact that there has been a provisional or conditional acceptance would not make any difference as a provisional or conditional acceptance cannot in itself make a binding contract.

precedents.case_name: Somasundaram Pillai v Provincial Government of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: provisional or conditional acceptance does not create a binding contract; enforceable contract requires unconditional acceptance
precedents.cited_holding: a provisional or conditional acceptance cannot in itself make a binding contract

precedents.citation: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangerkar v. The State of Bombay and others 1

anchor.surface_text: see Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangerkar v. The State of Bombay and others 1 . Where, however, a power or authority is conferred with a direction that certain regulation or formality shall be complied with, it seems neither unjust nor incorrect to exact a rigorous observance of it as essential to acquisition of the right or authority

precedents.case_name: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangerkar v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: prescriptions relating to public duties are directory if invalidating them would cause serious inconvenience or injustice
